div.p: THE DUENNA: A COMIC OPERA. IN THREE ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT GARDEN: WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE.
DUBLIN: MESSRS. G. BURNET, ABBEY-STREET, P. WO • AN, P.
BYRNE, W. JONES, AND J. MILLIKEN. 1794.

div.head: SCENE I. —A STREET.
div.stage: Enter LOPEZ, with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: LOPEZ.
sp.p:
PAST three o'clock! ſoh! a notable hour for one of my regular diſpoſition to be ſtrolling like a bravo thro' the ſtreets of Seville; well, of all ſervices, to ſerve a young lover is the hardeſt—not that I am an enemy to love; but my love and my maſter's differ ſtrangely—Don Ferdinand is much too gallant to eat, drink or ſleep—now, my love gives me an appetite—then I am fond of dreaming of my miſtreſs, and I love dearly to toaſt her—This cannot be done without good ſleep, and good liquor, hence my partiality to a feather bed and a bottle—what a pity now, that I have not further time for reflections; but my maſter expects thee, honeſt Lopez, to ſecure his retreat from
Donna Clara's window, as I gueſs [Muſic without] hey! ſure I heard muſic! ſo! ſo! who have we here? Oh, Don Antonio, my maſter's friend, come from the maſquerade to ſerenade my young miſtreſs, Donna Louiſa, I ſuppoſe! ſoh! we ſhall have the old gentleman up preſently—leſt he ſhould miſs his ſon, I had beſt loſe no time in getting to my poſt. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter ANTONIO, with Maſks and Muſic.

l.hi: Tell me, my lute, can thy ſoft ſtrain
So gently ſpeak thy maſter's pain;
So ſoftly ſing, ſo humbly ſigh,
That tho' my ſleeping love ſhall know
Who ſings—who ſighs below.
Her roſy ſlumbers ſhall not fly?
Thus may ſome viſion whiſper more
Than ever I dare ſpeak before.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Maſk.
sp.p: Antonio, your miſtreſs will never wake while you ſing ſo dolefully; love, like a cradled infant, is lull'd by a ſad melody.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: I do not wiſh to diſturb her reſt.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Maſk.
sp.p: The reaſon is, becauſe you know ſhe does not regard you enough, to appear if you waked her.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Then, I'll convince you.

l.hi: The breath of morn bids hence the night,
Unveil thoſe beauteous eyes, my fair,
Nor till the dawn of love is there,
I feel no day, I own no light.
Waking I heard thy numbers chide,
Waking, the dawn did bleſs my ſight,
'Tis Phoebus ſure that woos, I cry'd,
Who ſpeaks in ſong, who moves in light.
What vagabonds are theſe I hear
Fidling, fluting, rhyming, ranting,
Piping, ſcraping, whining, canting,
Fly, ſcurvy minſtrels, fly.
Nay, pray thee, father, why ſo rough?
An humble lover I,
How durſt you, daughter, lend an ear
To ſuch deceitful ſtuff?
Quick from the window fly.
Adieu, Antonio!
Muſi you go?
We ſoon perhaps, may meet again,
For tho' hard fortune is our foe,
The god of love will fight for us.
Reach me the blunderbuſs.
The god of love, who knows our pai •… ,
Hence, or theſe ſlugs are thro' your brain.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Truly, ſir, I think that a little ſleep once in a week or ſo—

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Peace, fool, don't mention ſleep to me.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p:
No, no, ſir, I don't mention your low-bred, vulgar, ſound ſleep; but I can't help thinking that a
gentle ſlumber, or half an hour's dozing, if it were only for the novelty of the thing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Peace, booby, I ſay, O Clara, dear, cruel diſturber of my reſt.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: And of mine too.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: S'death! to trifle with me at ſuch a juncture as this—now to ſtand on punctilios—love me! I don't believe ſhe ever did.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Nor I either.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Or is it that her ſex never know their deſires for an hour together.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Ah, they know them oftner than they'll own them.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Is there in the world ſo inconſtant a creature as Clara?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: I could name one.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yes; the tame fool who ſubmits to her caprice.

sp.speaker: Lopez
sp.p: I thought he cou'dn't miſs it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Is ſhe not capricious, teizing, tyrannical, obſtinate, perverſe, abſurd, ay, a wilderneſs of faults and follies, her looks are ſcorn, and her very ſmiles—s'death! I wiſh I hadn't mentioned her ſmiles; for ſhe does ſmile ſuch beaming lovelineſs, ſuch faſcinating brightneſs—O death and madneſs, I ſhall die if I loſe her.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: O thoſe damn'd ſmiles have undone all.

l.hi: Could I ber faults remember,
Forgetting ev'ry charm,
Soon would impartial reaſon
The tyrant love diſarm.
But when enraged I number
Each failing of her mind,
Love ſtill ſuggeſts each beauty.
And ſees—while reaſon's blind.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Here comes Don Antonio, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well, go you home—I ſhall be there preſently.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Ah thoſe curſt ſmiles. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Antonio, Lopez tells me he left you chaunting before our door—was my father wak'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes; he has a ſingular affection for muſic, ſo I left him roaring at his barr'd window like the print of Bajazet in the cage. And what brings you out ſo early?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I believe I told you that to morrow was the day fix'd by Don Pedro and Clara's unnatural ſtep-mother, for her to enter a convent, in order that her brat might poſſeſs her fortune, made deſperate by this, I procur'd a key to the door, and birb'd Clara's maid to leave it unbolted; at two this morning I entered, unperceived, and ſtole to her chamber—I found her waking and weeping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Happy Ferdinand!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, hear the concluſion—I was rated as the moſt confident ruffian, for daring to approach her room at that hour of night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ay, ay, this was at firſt.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: No ſuch thing! ſhe would not hear a word from me, but threatened to raiſe her mother if I did not inſtantly leave her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well; but at laſt?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: At laſt! why I was forced to leave the houſe as he came in.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And did you do nothing to offend her?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Nothing, as I hope to be ſaved—I believe I might ſnatch a dozen or two of kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Was that all? well, I think I never heard of ſuch aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Zounds! I tell you I behaved with the utmoſt reſpect.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O lord! I don't mean you, but in her—but, hark'y', Ferdinand, did you leave your key with them?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yes; the maid who ſaw me out took it from the door.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then my life for it, her miſtreſs elopes after you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Ay, to bleſs my rival perhaps—I am in a humour to ſuſpect every body—you lov'd her once, and thought her an angel, as I do now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Yes, I loved her till I found ſhe wou'dn't love me, and then I diſcovered that ſhe hadn't a good feature in her face.
AIR.
I ne'er could any luſtre ſee
In eyes that would not look on me:
I ne'er ſaw nectar on a lip,
But where my own did hope to ſip.
Has the maid who ſeeks my heart
Cheeks of roſe untouch'd by art?
I will own the colour true,
When yielding bluſhes aid their hue.
Is her hand ſo ſoft and pure?
I muſt preſs it to be ſure:
Nor can I be certain then
'Till it grateful preſs again:
Muſt I with attentive eye
Watch her heaving boſom ſigh?
I will do ſo when I ſee
That heaving boſom ſigh for me.
Beſides, Ferdinand, you have full ſecurity in my love for your ſiſter, help me there, and I can never diſturb you with Clara.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: As far as I can conſiſtently with the honour of our family, you know I will; but there muſt be no eloping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And yet now, you would carry off Clara.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Ay, that's a different caſe, we never mean that others ſhould act to our ſiſters and wives as we do
to others—But to-morrow Clara is to be forc'd into a convent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well: and am not I ſo unfortunately circumſtanc'd? To-morrow your father forces Louiſa to marry Iſaac, the Portugueze—but come with me, and we'll deviſe ſomething, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I muſt go home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, adieu.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But, Antonio, if you did not love my ſiſter, you have too much honour and friendſhip to ſupplant me with Clara.

l.hi: Friendſhip is the bond of reaſon,
But if beauty diſapprove,
Heaven diſſolves all other treaſon
In the heart that's true to love.
The faith which to my friend I ſwore
As a civil oath I view,
But to the charms which I adore,
'Tis religion to be true.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
There is always a levity in Antonio's manner of replying to me on this ſubject, that is very alarming—'Sdeath, if Clara ſhould love him after all.
AIR.
Tho' cauſe for ſuſpicion appears,
Yet proofs of her love too are ſtrong;
I'm a wretch if I'm right in my fears,
And unworthy of bliſs if I'm wrong.
What heart-breaking torments from jealouſy flow,
Ah, none but the jealous, the jealous can know.
When bleſt with the ſmiles of my fair,
I know not how much I adore;
Thoſe ſmiles let another but ſhare,
And I wonder I priz'd them no more.
Then whence can I hope a relief from my woe,
When the falſer ſhe ſeems ſtill the fonder I grow.

div.head: SCENE —A room in Don JEROME's houſe.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But my dear Margaret, my charming Duenna, do you think we ſhall ſucceed?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: I tell you again I have no doubt on't; but it muſt be inſtantly put to the trial—Every thing is prepared in your room, and for the reſt we muſt truſt to fortune.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My father's oath was never to ſee me till I had conſented to—

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: I was thus I overheard him ſay to his friend, Don Guzman, "I will demand of her tomorrow, once for all, whether ſhe will conſent to marry Iſaac Mendoza—If ſhe heſitates, I will make a ſolemn oath never to ſee or ſpeak to her till ſhe returns to her duty"—theſe were his words.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And on his known obſtinate adherence to what he has once ſaid, you have form'd this plan for my eſcape—But have you ſecured my maid in our intereſt?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: She is a party in the whole—but remember, if we ſucceed, you reſign all right and title in little Iſaac the Jew, over to me.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
That I do with all my ſoul, get him if you can, and I ſhall wiſh you joy moſt heartily. He is twenty times as rich as my poor Antonio.
AIR.
Thou cans't not boaſt of fortune's ſtore,
My love, vhile me they wealthy call,
But I was glad to find thee poor,
For with my heart I'd give thee all.
And then the grateful youth ſhall own,
I lov'd him for himſelf alone.
But when his worth my hand ſhall gain,
No word or look of mine ſhall ſhew,
That I, the ſmalleſt thought retain
Of what my bounty did beſtow.
Yet ſtill his grateful heart ſhall own,
I lov'd him for himſelf alone.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: I hear Don Jerome coming—Quick, give me the laſt letter I brought you from Antonio—you know that is to be the ground of my diſmiſſion—I muſt ſlip out to ſeal it up as undelivered. [Exit

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: What, I ſuppoſe you have been ſerenading too! Eh, diſturbing ſome peaceable neighbourhood with villainous catgut and laſcivious piping, out on't! you ſet your ſiſter here a vile example—but I come to tell you, madam, that I'll ſuffer no more of theſe midnight incantations, theſe amorous orgies that ſteal the ſenſes in the hearing; as they ſay Egyptian embalmers ſerve mummies, extracting the brain thro' the ears; however, there's an end of your frolics—Iſaac Mendoza will be here preſently, and to-morrow you ſhall marry him.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Never while I have life.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I wonder how you can think of ſuch a man for a ſon-in-law.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Sir, you are very kind to favour me with your ſentiments—and pray, what is your objection to him?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: He is a Portugueze in the firſt place.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: No ſuch thing, boy, he has forſworn his country.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: He is a Jew.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Another miſtake: he has been a Chriſtian theſe ſix weeks.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Ay, he has left his old religion for an eſtate, and has not had time to get a new one,

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But ſtands like a dead wall between church and ſynagogue, or like the blank leaves between the Old and New Teſtament.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Any thing more?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But the moſt remarkable part of his character, is his paſſion for deceit, and tricks of cunning.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Tho' at the ſame time, the fool predominates ſo much over the knave, that I am told he is generally the dupe of his own art.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: True, like an unſkilful gunner, he uſually miſſes his aim, and is hurt by the recoil of his own piece.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Any thing more?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: To ſum up all, he has the worſt fault a huſband can have—he's not my choice.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: But you are his; and choice on one ſide is ſufficient—two lovers ſhould never meet in marriage—be you ſour as you pleaſe, he is ſweet-temper'd, and for your good fruit, there's nothing like ingrafting on a crab.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I deteſt him as a lover, and ſhall ten times more as a huſband.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: I don't know that—marriage generally makes a great change—but to cut the matter ſhort, will you have him or not?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: There is nothing elſe I could diſobey you in.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Do you value your father's peace?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So much, that I will not faſten on him the regret of making an only daughter wretched.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
Very well, ma'am, then mark me—never more will I ſee or converſe with you till you return to your duty—no reply—this and your chamber ſhall be
your apartments, I never will ſtir out without leaving you under lock and key, and when I'm at home no creature can approach you but thro' my library—we'll try who can be moſt obſtinate—out of my ſight—There remain till you know your duty. [Puſhes her out.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Surely, ſir, my ſiſter's inclinations ſhould be conſulted in a matter of this kind, and ſome regard paid to Don Antonio, being my particular friend.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: That, doubtleſs, is a very great recommendation—I certainly have not paid ſufficient reſpect to it.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: There is not a man living I would ſooner chuſe for a brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Very poſſible; and if you happen to have e'er a ſiſter, who is not at the ſame time a daughter of mine, I'm ſure I ſhall have no objection to the relationſhip—but at preſent, if you pleaſe, we'll drop the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Nay, ſir, 'tis only my regard for my ſiſter makes me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Then, pray, ſir, in future, let your regard for your father make you hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I have done, ſir—I ſhall only add a wiſh that you would reflect what at our age you would have felt, had you been croſt in your affection for the mother of her you are ſo ſevere to.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
Why I muſt confeſs I had a great affection for your mother's ducats, but that was all, boy—I married her for her fortune, and ſhe took me in obedience to her father, and a very happy couple we were—we never expected any love from one another, and ſo we were never diſappointed—If we grumbled a little now and then, it was ſoon over, for we were never fond enough to quarrel, and when the good woman died, why, why—I had as lieve ſhe had lived, and I wiſh every widower in Seville could ſay the ſame—I ſhall now go and get the key of this dreſſing room—So, good ſon, if you have any lecture in
ſupport of diſobedience to give your ſiſter, it muſt be brief; ſo make the beſt of your time d'ye hear. [Exit Jerome.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I fear indeed, my friend Antonio, has little to hope for—however Louiſa has firmneſs, and my father's anger will probably only increaſe her affection—In our intercourſe with the world, it is natural for us to diſlike thoſe who are innocently the cauſe of our diſtreſs; but in the heart's attachment, a woman never likes a man with ardour till ſhe has ſuffered for his ſake [Noiſe] Soh! what buſtle is here! between my father and the Duenna too—I'll e'en get out of the way. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Don JEROME (with a letter) putting in the DUENNA.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: I'm aſtoniſhed! I'm thunder ſtruck! here's treachery and conſpiracy with a vengeance! you, Antonio's creature, and chief manager of this plot for my daughter's eloping! you that I placed here as a ſcare-crow.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: A ſcare-crow—To prove a decoy-duck—what have you to ſay for yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Well, ſir, ſince you have forced that letter from me, and diſcovered my real ſentiments, I ſcorn to renounce 'em—I am Antonio's friend, and it was my intention that your daughter ſhould have ſerv'd you as all ſuch old tyrannical ſots ſhould be ſerv'd—I delight in the tender paſſions, and would befriend all under their influence.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: The tender paſſions! yes, they would become thoſe impenetrable features—why, thou deceitful hag! I plac'd thee as a guard to the rich bloſſoms of my daughter's beauty—I thought that dragon's front of thine would cry aloof to the ſons of gallantry—ſteel traps and ſpring guns ſeem'd writ in every wrinkle of it—but you ſhall quit my houſe this inſtant—the tender paſſions, indeed! go, thou wanton ſybil, thou amorous woman of Endor, go!

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: You baſe, ſcurrilous old—but I won't demean myſelf by naming what you are—yes, ſavage, I'll leave your den, but I ſuppoſe you don't mean to detain my apparel—I may have my things I preſume.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: I took you, miſtreſs, with your wardrobe on—what have you pilfer'd, heh?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt take leave of my miſtreſs, ſhe has valuables of mine, beſides, my cardinal and veil are in her room.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Your veil forſooth! what, do you dread being gazed at? or are you afraid of your complexion? well, go take your leave, and get your veil and cardinal! ſoh! you quit the houſe within theſe five minutes—In—in—quick [Exit Duenna.

Here was a precious plot of miſchief! theſe are the comforts daughters bring us.
AIR.
If a daughter you have ſhe's the plague of your life,
No peace ſhall you know, tho' you've buried your wife,
At twenty ſhe mocks at the duty you taught her,
O, what a plague is an obſtinate daughter!
Sighing and whining,
Dying and pining,
O, what a plague is an obſtinate daughter!
When ſcarce in their teens, they have wit to perplex us,
With letters and lovers for ever they vex us,
While each ſtill rejects the fair ſuitor you've brought her,
O, what a plague is an obſtinate daughter!
Wrangling and jangling,
Flouting and pouting,
O, what a plague is an obſtinate daughter!

div.stage: Enter LOUISA dreſs'd as the DUENNA, with Cardinal and Veil, and ſeeming to cry.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
This way, miſtreſs, this way—what, I warrant, a tender parting—ſoh! tears of turpentine
down thoſe deal cheeks—Aye, you may well hide your head—yes, whine till your heart breaks, but I'll not hear one word of excuſe—ſo you are right to be dumb, this way—this way.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: So ſpeed you well, ſagacious Don Jerome! O, rare effects of paſſion and obſtinacy—now ſhall I try whether I can't play the fine lady as well as my miſtreſs, and if I ſucceed, I may be a fine lady for the reſt of my life—I'll loſe no time to equip myſelf. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV. The Court before DON JEROME's houſe.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Come, miſtreſs, there is your way—The world lies before you, ſo troop, thou antiquated Eve, thou original ſin—hold, yonder is ſome fellow ſkulking, perhaps it is Antonio—go to him, d'ye hear, and tell him to make you amends, and as he has got you turn'd away, tell him I ſay it is but juſt he ſhou'd take you himſelf, go.
Soh! I am rid of her, thank heaven! and now I ſhall be able to keep my oath, and confine my daughter with better ſecurity. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE V. —The PIAZZA.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But where madam, is it you intend to go?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Any where to avoid the ſelfiſh violence of my mother-in-law, and Ferdinand's inſolent importunity.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Indeed, ma'am, ſince we have profited by
Don Ferdinand's key in making our eſcape, I think we had beſt find him, if it were only to thank him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No—he has offended me exceedingly. [Retire.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So, I have ſucceeded in being turn'd out of doors—but how ſhall I find Antonio? I dare not enquire for him for fear of being diſcovered; I would ſend to my friend Clara, but that I doubt her prudery wou'd condemn me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Then ſuppoſe, ma'am, you were to try if your friend Donna Louiſa would not receive you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No, her notions of filial duty are ſo ſevere, ſhe would certainly betray me.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Clara is of a cold temper, and would this ſtep of mine highly forward.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Louiſa's reſpect for her father is ſo great, ſhe would not credit the unkindneſs of mine. [Louiſa turns, and ſees Clara and Maid.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ha! who are thoſe? ſure one is Clara—if it be, I'll truſt her—Clara! [Advances.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Louiſa! and in Maſquerade too!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You will be more ſurprized when I tell you that I have run away from my father.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Surprized indeed! and I ſhould certainly chide you moſt horridly, only that I have juſt run away from mine.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My dear Clara! [Embrace.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Dear ſiſter truant! and whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: To find the man I love to be ſure—And I preſume you wou'd have no averſion to meet with my brother.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Indeed I ſhould—he has behaved ſo ill to me, I don't believe I ſhall ever forgive him.

l.hi: When ſable night, each drooping plant reſtoring,
Wept o'er the flowers her breath did cheer,
As ſome ſad widow o'er her babe deploring,
Wakes its beauty with a tear;
When all did ſleep, whoſe weary hearts did borrow
One hour from love and care to reſt,
Lo! as I preſt my couch in ſilent ſorrow,
My lover caught me to his breaſt;
He vowed he came to ſave me
From thoſe who would enſlave me!
Then kneeling,
Kiſſes ſtealing.
Endleſs faith he ſwore,
But ſoon I •… hid him thence
For had his fond pretence,
Obtain'd o •… e favour then,
And he had preſs d •… gain
I fear'd my treacherous heart might grant him more.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Well, for all this, I would have ſent him to plead his pardon, but that I would not yet a while have him know of my flight. And where do you hope to find protection?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: The lady Abbeſs of the convent of St. Catherine is a relation and kind friend of mine—I ſhall be ſecure with her, and you had beſt go thither with me.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No; I am determined to find Antonio firſt, and as I live, here comes the very man I will employ to ſeek him for me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Who is he? he's a ſtrange figure!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, that ſweet creature is the man whom my father has fixed on for my huſband.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And will you, ſpeak to him? Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: He is the fitteſt man in the world for my purpoſe—for, tho' I was to have married him tomorrow, he is the only man in Seville, who, I am ſure never ſaw me in his life.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And how do you know him?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: He arrived but yeſterday, and he was ſhewn me from the window as he viſited my father.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Well, I'll be gone

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Hold, my dear Clara—a thought has ſtruck me, will you give me leave to borrow your name as I ſee occaſion.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It will but diſgrace you—but uſe it as you pleaſe—I dare not ſtay (going) but, Louiſa, if you ſhould ſee your brother, be ſure you don't inform him that I have taken refuge with the Dame Prior of the convent of St. Catherine, on the left hand ſide of the Piazza which leads to the church of St Anthony.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I'll be very particular in my directions where he may not find you. [Exeunt. Clara and Maid.] So! my ſwain yonder has done admiring himſelf and draws nearer. [Retires.

div.stage: Enter ISAAC and CARLOS, ISAAC with a pocket glaſs.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: (Looking in the glaſs.) I tell you, friend Carlos, I will pleaſe myſelf in the habit of my chin.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But, my dear friend, how can you think to pleaſe a lady with ſuch a face?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with the face? I think it is a very engaging face; and I am ſure a lady muſt have very little taſte, who could diſlike my beard (Sees Louiſa.) See now—I'll die if here is not a little damſel ſtruck with it already.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Signor, are you diſpoſed to oblige a lady who greatly wants your aſſiſtance? [Unveils.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, a very pretty black-eyed girl; ſhe has certainly taken a fancy to me, Carlos—firſt ma'am. I muſt beg the favour of your name.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Soh! It's well I am provided. (aſide.) My name, ſir, is Donna Clara D'Almanza.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: What!—Don Guzman's daughter? I'faith, I juſt now heard ſhe was miſſing.

sp.speaker: Louiſa:
sp.p: But ſure, ſir, you have too much gallantry and honor to betray me, whoſe fault is love.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: So! a paſſion for me! poor girl! why, ma'am, as for betraying you, I don't ſee how I could get any thing by it; ſo you may rely on my honour; but as for your love, I am ſorry your caſe is ſo deſperate.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Why ſo, ſignor?

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Becauſe I'm poſitively engaged to another—an't I, Carlos?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Nay, but hear me.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, no; what ſhould I hear for? It is impoſſible for me to court you in an honourable way; and for any thing elſe, if I were to comply now; I ſuppoſe you have ſome ungrateful brother, or couſin, who would want to cut my throat for my civility—ſo, truly you had beſt go home again.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Odious wretch! (aſide) But, good ſignor, it is Antonio d'Ercilla, on whoſe account I have eloped.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: How! what! it is not with me then, that you are in love?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No indeed it is not.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Then you are a forward, impertinent ſimpleton! and I ſhall certainly acquaint your father.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Is this your gallantry

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yet hold—Antonio d'Ercilla did you ſay? egad, I may make ſomething of this—Antonio d'Ercilla?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, and if ever you hope to proſper in love, you will bring me to him.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: By St. Iago, and I will too—Carlos, this Antonio is one who rivals me (as I have heard) with Louiſa—now, if I could hamper him with this girl, I ſhould have the field to myſelf, hey, Carlos! A lucky thought, isn't it?—

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Yes, very good—very good—

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Ah, this little brain is never at a loſs—cunning Iſaac! cunning rogue! Donna Clara, will you truſt yourſelf awhile to my friend's direction?

sp.speaker: Louſa.
sp.p: May I rely on you, good ſignor?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Lady, it is impoſſible I ſhould deceive you.
AIR.
Had I a heart for falſhood fram'd
I ne'er could injure you;
For tho' your tongue no promiſe claim'd,
Your charms would make me true.
To you no ſoul ſhall bear deceit,
No ſtranger offer wrong,
But friends in all the ag d you'll meet;
And lovers in the young.
But when they learn that you have bleſt
Another with your heart,
They'll bid aſpiring paſſions reſt,
And act a brother's part;
Then, lady, dread not here deceit,
Nor fear to ſuffer wrong;
For friends in all the ag'd you'll meet,
And lovers in the young.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I'll conduct the lady to my lodgings, Carlos; I muſt haſte to Don Jerome—perhaps you know Louiſa, ma'am. She is divinely handſome—isn't ſhe?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me not joining with you.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, I have heard it on all hands.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Her father is uncommonly partial to her, but I believe you will find ſhe has rather a matronly air.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Carlos, this is all envy—you pretty girls never ſpeak well of one another—harky', find out Antonio, and I'll ſaddle him with this ſcrape, I warrant! oh, 'twas the luckieſt thought—Donna Clara, your very obedient—Carlos, to your poſt.

l.hi: My miſtreſs expects me and I muſt go to her,
Or how can I hope for a ſmile?
Soon may you return a proſperous wooer,
But think what I ſuffer the while:
Alone and away from the man whom I love,
In ſtranger I'm forc'd to confide,
Dear lady my friend you may truſt and, he'll prove,
Your ſervant, protector, and guide.
Gentle maid, ah! why ſuſpect me?
Let me ſerve thee—then reject me,
Can'ſt thou truſt, and I deceive thee?
Art thou ſad, and ſhall I grieve thee?
Gentle maid, ab! why ſuſpect me?
Let me ſerve thee—then reject me.
Never may'ſt thou happy be,
If in aught thou'rt falſe to me.
Never may be happy be,
If in aught he's falſe to thee.
Never may I happy be,
If in aught I'm falſe to thee.
Never may'ſt thou &c.
Never may be &c.
Never may I &c.

div.head: SCENE I —A Library in Jerome's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! run away from her father! has ſhe given him the ſlip! Ha, ha, ha! poor Don Guzman!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Ay; and I am to conduct her to Antonio; by which means you ſee I ſhall hamper him ſo that he can give me no diſturbance with your daughter—this is trap, isn't it? a nice ſtroke of cunning, heh!

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Excellent! Excellent! yes, yes, carry her to him, hamper him by all means, ha, ha, ha! poor Don Guzman! an old fool! impoſed on by a girl!

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Nay, they have the cunning of ſerpents, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Pſha! they are cunning only when they have fools to deal with—why don't my girl play me ſuch a trick—let her cunning over-reach my caution, I ſay—heh little Iſaac!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: True, true; or let me ſee any of the ſex make a fool of me—No, no, egad, little Solomon, (as my aunt uſed to call me) underſtands tricking a little too well.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Ay, but ſuch a driveller as Don Guzman.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: And ſuch a dupe as Antonia.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: True; ſure never were ſeen ſuch a couple of credulous ſimpletons, but come, 'tis time you ſhould ſee my daughter—you muſt carry on the ſiege by yourſelf, friend Iſaac,

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Sir, you'll introduce—

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
No—I have ſworn a ſolemn oath not to ſee or ſpeak to her till ſhe renounces her diſobedience:
win her to that, and ſhe gains a father and a huſband at once.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p:
Gad, I ſhall never be able to deal with her alone; nothing keeps me in ſuch awe as perfect beauty—now there is ſomething conſoling and encouraging in uglineſs.
SONG.
Give Iſaac the nymph who no beauty can boaſt;
But health and good humour to make her his toaſt,
If ſtrait, I don't mind whether ſlender or ſat,
And ſix feet or four—well ne'er quarrel for that.
Whate'er her complexion, I vow I don't care,
If brown it is laſting more pleaſing if fair;
And tho' in her face I no dimples ſhou'd ſee,
Let her ſmile, and each dell is a dimple to me.
Let her locks be the reddeſt that ever were ſeen,
And her eyes may be e'en any colour but green,
Be they light, grey or black, their luſtre and hue,
I ſwear I've no choice, only let her have two.
'Tis true I'd diſpenſe with a throne on her back,
And white teeth I own, are genteeler than black,
A little round chin too's a beauty I've heard,
But I only deſire ſhe may'nt have a heard.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: You will change your note, my friend, when you've ſeen Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O Don Jerome, the honour of your alliance—

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Aye, but her beauty will affect you—ſhe is, tho' I ſay it, who am her father, a very prodigy—there you will ſee Peatures with an eye like mine—yes I'faith, there is a kind of wicked ſparkling—ſomething of a roguiſh brightneſs that ſhews her to be my own.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Pretty rogue!

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Then, when ſhe ſmiles, you'll ſee a little dimple in one cheek only; a beauty it is certainly, yet you ſhall not ſay which is prettieſt, the cheek with the dimple, or the cheek without.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Pretty rogue!

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Then the roſes on thoſe cheeks are ſhaded with a ſort of velvet down, that gives a delicacy to the glow of health.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Pretty rogue!

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Her ſkin pure dimity, yet more fair, being ſpangled here and there with a golden freckle.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Charming pretty rogue! how is the tone of her voice?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Remarkably pleaſing—but if you cou'd prevail on her to ſing you would be enchanted—ſhe is a nightingale—a Virginia nightingale—but come, come, her maid ſhall conduct you to her Antichamber.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, egad, I'll pluck up reſolution and meet her frowns intrepidly.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Aye! who her briſkly—win her and give me a proof of your addreſs, my little Solomon.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: But hold—I expect my friend Carlos to call on me here—If he comes will you ſend him to me?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: I will—Lauretta, come—ſhe'll ſhew you to the room—what! do you droop? here's a mournful face to make love with.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Sir, my miſtreſs will wait on you preſently. [Goes to the door.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: When ſhe's at leiſure—don't hurry her. [Exit Maid.

I wiſh I had ever practiſed a love-ſcene—I doubt I ſhall make a poor figure—I cou'd'nt be more afraid if I was going before the Inquiſition—ſo! the door
opens—yes, ſhe's coming—the very ruſtling of her ſilk has a diſdainful ſound.
Now dar'n't I look round for the ſoul of me—her beauty will certainly ſtrike me dumb if I do. I wiſh ſhe'd ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Sir, I attend your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: So! the ice is broke, and a pretty civil beginning too! hem! madam—Miſs—I'm all attention.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Nay, ſir, 'tis I who ſhou'd liſten, and you propoſe.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, this is'nt ſo diſdainful neither—I believe I may venture to look—No—I dar'n't—one glance of thoſe roguiſh ſparklers wou'd fix me again.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: You ſeem thoughtful, Sir—let me perſuade you to ſit down.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: So, ſo; ſhe mollifies apace—ſhe's ſtruck with my figure, this attitude has had its effect.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Come, ſir, here's a chair.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Madam, the greatneſs of your goodneſs overpowers me—that a lady ſo lovely ſhou'd deign to turn her beauteous eyes on me ſo. [She takes his hand, he turns and ſees her.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurpriz'd at my condeſcenſion.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, yes, madam, I am a little ſurprized at it; zounds! this can never be Louiſa—ſhe's as old as my mother. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: But former prepoſſeſſions give way to my father's commands.

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: (aſide,) Her father! Yes, 'tis ſhe then—Lord, lord; how blind ſome parents are!

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Signor Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Truly, the little damſel was right—ſhe has rather a matronly air indeed! ah! 'tis well my affections are fixed on her fortune and not her perſon.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Signor, won't you ſit? (ſhe ſits.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p:
Pardon me, madam, I have ſcarce recover'd
my aſtoniſhment at—your condeſcenſion, madam—ſhe has the devil's own dimples to be ſure. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Nay, you ſhall not ſtand (he ſits) I do not wonder, ſir, that you are ſurpriz'd at my affability—I own, Signor, that I was vaſtly prepoſſeſſed againſt you, and being teiz'd by my father, I did give ſome encouragement to Antonio, But then, ſir, you were deſcribed to me as a quite different perſon.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye, and ſo you was to me upon my ſoul, madam.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: But when I ſaw you, I was never more ſtruck in my life.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: That was juſt my caſe too, madam; I was ſtruck all on a heap for my part.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I ſee our miſapprehenſion has been mutual—you expected to find me haughty and averſe, and I was taught to believe you a little black ſnub-noſed fellow, without perſon, manners or addreſs.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, I wiſh ſhe had anſwer'd her picture as well.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: But, ſir, your air is noble—ſomething ſo liberal in your carriage, with ſo penetrating an eye, and ſo bewitching a ſmile.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, now I look at her again, I don't think ſhe is ſo ugly.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: So little like a jew, and ſo much like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, certainly there is ſomething pleaſing in the tone of her voice.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: You will pardon this breach of decorum in praiſing you thus, but my joy at being ſo agreeably deceiv'd has given me ſuch a flow of ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O dear lady, may I thank thoſe dear lips for this goodneſs (kiſſes her) why, ſhe has a pretty ſort of velvet down, that's the truth on't. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: O ſir, you have the moſt inſinuating manner, but indeed you ſhou'd get rid of that odious heard—one might as well kiſs an hedge hog.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes ma'am the razor wou'd'nt be amiſs for either of us (aſide) Could you ſavour me with a ſong?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Willingly, ſir, tho' I am rather hoarſe—Ahem! [Begins to ſing.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Very like a Virginia nightingale—ma'am, I perceive you're hoarſe—I beg you will not diſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p:
O not in the leaſt diſtreſſed;—now, ſir.
SONG.
When a tender maid
Is firſt eſſayed,
By ſome admiring ſwain,
How her bluſhes riſe,
If ſhe meets his eyes,
While he unfolds his pain;
If he takes her hand, ſhe trembles quite,
Touch her lips, and ſhe ſwoons outright,
While a pit a pat, &c.
Her heart avows her fright.
But in time appear,
Fewer ſigns of fear,
Tho' youth ſhe boldly views,
If her hand he graſps,
Or her boſom claſps,
No mantling bluſh enſues.
Then to church well pleas'd the lovers move,
While her ſmiles her contentment prove,
And a pit a pat, &c.
Her heart avows her love.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Charming, ma'am! Enchanting! and truly your notes put me in mind of one that's very dear to me, a lady indeed, whom you greatly reſemble.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: How! is there then another ſo dear to you?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O, no, ma'am, you miſtake; it was my mother I meant.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Come, ſir, I ſee you are amazed and confounded at my condeſcenſion, and know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: It is very true indeed, ma'am—but it is a judgment, I look on it as a judgment on me for delaying to urge the time when you'll permit me to compleat my happineſs, by acquainting Don Jerome with your condeſcenſion.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt frankly own to you that I can never be your's with my father's conſent.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Good lack! how ſo?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: When my father in his paſſion ſwore he would never ſee me again 'till I acquieſced in his will—I alſo made a vow that I would never take a huſband from his hand—nothing ſhall make me break that oath—but if you have ſpirit and contrivance enough to carry me off without his knowledge, I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Nay, ſir, if you heſitate—

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I'faith no bad whim this—if I take her at her word, I ſhall ſecure her fortune, and avoid making any ſettlement in return; thus I ſhall not only cheat the lover but the father too, Oh! cunning rogue, Iſaac! Ay, ay, let this little brain alone—Egad, I'll take her in the mind.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Well, ſir, what's your determination?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Madam, I was dumb only from rapture—I applaud your ſpirit, and joyfully cloſe with your propoſal; for which, thus let me on this lilly hand expreſs my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Well, ſir, you muſt get my father's conſent to walk with me in the garden. But by no means inform him of my kindneſs to you.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, to be ſure—that wou'd ſpoil all—But truſt me when tricking is the word—let me alone for a piece of cunning; this very day you ſhall be out of his power.

sp.speaker: Duenna
sp.p: Well, I leave the management of it all to you, I perceive plain, ſir, that you are not one that can be eaſily outwitted.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, you're right, madam—you're right I'faith.
Here's a gentleman at the door, who begs permiſſion to ſpeak with Signor Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: A friend of mine, ma'am, and a truſty friend—Let him come in. [Exit Maid.
He is one to be depended on, ma'am.
So, coz. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Carlos
sp.p: I have left Donna Clara at your lodgings; but can no where find Antonio.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well I will ſearch him out myſelf—Carlos, you rogue, I thrive, I proſper.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Where is your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: There, you booby, there ſhe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Why ſhe's damn'd ugly.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Huſh! [Stops his mouth.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: What is your friend ſaying, Signor?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O ma'am, he is expreſſing his raptures at ſuch charms as he never ſaw before, hey Carlos?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Aye, ſuch as I never ſaw before, indeed.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: You are a very obliging Gentleman—well, Signor Iſaac, I believe we had better part for the preſent. Remember our plan.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O, ma'am, it is written in my heart, fixed as the image of thoſe divine beauties—adieu, Idol of my ſoul—yet, once more permit me.— [kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Duenna
sp.p: Sweet, courteous ſir, adieu.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Your ſlave eternally—come Carlos, ſay ſomething civil at taking leave.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I'faith, Iſaac, ſhe is the hardeſt woman to compliment I ever ſaw, however, I'll try ſomething I had ſtudied for the occaſion.

l.hi: Ah! ſure a pair was never ſeen,
Si juſtly form'd to meet by nature.
The youth excelling ſo in mien,
The maid in every grace of feature.
O how hap'y are ſuch lovers,
When kindred beauties each diſcovers.
For ſurely ſhe
Was made for thee,
And thou to bleſs this lovely creature.
So mild your looks, your children thence,
Will early learn the taſk of duty,
The boys with all their father's ſenſe,
The girls with all their mother's beauty.
Oh! how happy to inherit,
At once ſuch graces and ſuch ſpirit.
Thus while you live
May fortune give,
Each bleſſing equal to your merit.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Object to Antonio? I have ſaid it! his poverty, can you acquit him of that?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, I own he is not over rich—but he is of as antient and honourable a family as any in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Yes, I know the beggars are a very ancient family in moſt kingdoms; but never in great repute, boy.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Antonio, ſir, has many amiable qualities.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: But he is poor, can you clear him of that, I ſay—is he not a gay, diſſipated take, who has ſquander'd his patrimony?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, he inherited but little; and that his generoſity, more than his profuſeneſs, has ſtript him of—but he has never ſullied his honor, which, with his title, has outlived his means.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Pſha! you talk like a blockhead! nobilility without an eſtate is as ridiculous as gold-lace on a frize-coat.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: This language, ſir, wou'd better become a Dutch or Engliſh trader, than a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
Yes; and thoſe Dutch and Engliſh traders, as you call them, are the wiſer people. Why, booby, in England they were formerly as nice as to birth and family as we are—but they have long diſcover'd
what a wonderful purifier gold is—and now no one there regards pedigree in any thing but a horſe—O, here comes Iſaac! I hope he has proſper'd in his ſuit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Doubtleſs, that agreeable figure of his muſt have help'd his ſuit ſurprizingly.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: How now? [Ferd. walks aſide.
Well, my friend, have you ſoften'd her?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O yes; I have ſoften'd her.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: What, does ſhe come to?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, truly, ſhe was kinder than I expected to find her.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: And the dear little Angel was civil, hey!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, the pretty little Angel was very civil.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: I'm tranſported to hear it, well, and you were aſtoniſhed at her beauty, hey?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I was aſtoniſhed indeed! pray, how old is miſs?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: How old? let me ſee—eight and twelve—ſhe is twenty.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Twenty?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Aye, to a month.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Then, upon my ſoul, ſhe is the oldeſt looking girl of her age in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Do you think ſo? but I believe you will not ſee a prettier girl.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Here and there one.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Louiſa has the family face.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, egad, I ſhou'd have taken it for a family face, and one that has been in the family ſome time too. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: She has her father's eyes.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Truly I ſhou'd have gueſs'd them to have been ſo—If ſhe had her mother's ſpectacles I believe ſhe would not ſee the worſe. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Her aunt Urſula's noſe, and her grandmother's forehead.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Ay, faith, and her grandmother's chin to a hair. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Well, if ſhe was but as dutiful as ſhe's handſome—and harky, friend Iſaac, ſhe is none of your made up beauties—her charms are of the laſting kind.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I ſaith, ſo they ſhou'd—for if ſhe be but twenty now, ſhe may double her age, before her years will overtake her face.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, zounds, maſter Iſaac, you are not ſneering, are you?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, now ſeriouſly, Don Jerome, do you think your daughter handſome?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: By this light, ſhe's as handſome a girl as any in Seville.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Then, by theſe eyes, I think her as plain a woman as ever I beheld.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: By St. Iago you muſt be blind.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis you are partial.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: How! have I neither ſenſe nor taſte? If a fair ſkin, fine eyes, teeth of ivory, with a lovely bloom, and a delicate ſhape—if theſe, with a heavenly voice, and a world of grace, are not charms, I know not what you call beautiful.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Good lack, with what eyes a father ſees! As I have life, ſhe is the very reverſe of all this, as for the dimity ſkin you told me of, I ſwear 'tis a thorough nankeen as ever I ſaw; for her eyes, their utmoſt merit is in not ſquinting—for her teeth, where there is one of ivory; its neighbour is pure ebony, black and white alternately, juſt like the keys of an harpſicord. Then as to her ſinging, and heavenly voice—by this hand, ſhe has a ſhrill crack'd pipe, that ſounds for all the world like a child's trumpet.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, you little Hebrew ſcoundrel, do you mean to inſult me? out of my houſe, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Dear ſir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, this Iſraelite here, has the impudence to ſay your ſiſter's ugly.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: He muſt be either blind or inſolent.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: So, I find they are all in a ſtory. Egad, I believe I have gone too far.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sure, ſir, there muſt be ſome miſtake—It can't be my ſiſter whom he has ſeen.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: S'death! you are as great a fool as he, what miſtake can there be? did not I lock up Louiſa, and hav'n't I the key in my own pocket? And didn't her maid ſhew him into the dreſſing room? and yet you talk of a miſlake, no, the Portugueze meant to inſult me—and, but that this roof protects him, old as I am, this ſword ſhou'd do me juſtice.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I muſt get off as well as I can—her fortune is not the leſs handſome.

l.hi: Believe me, good Sir, I ne'er meant to offend,
My miſtreſs I love, and I value my friend:
To win her, and wed her, is ſtill my requeſt,
For better, for worſe, and I ſwear I don't jeſt.
Zounds! you'd beſt not provoke me, my rage is ſo high.
Hold him faſt, I beſeech you, his rage is ſo high,
Good Sir, you're too hot and this place I muſt fly.
You're a knave and a ſot, and this place you'd beſt fly.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Don Jerome, come now, let us lay aſide all joking and be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I'll be hang'd if you hav'n't taken my abuſe of your daughter ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: You meant it ſo, did not you?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O mercy, no! a joke—juſt to try how angry it wou'd make you.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
Was that all I'faith! I did'n't know you
had been ſuch a wag; ha, ha, ha! By St. Iago, you made me very angry tho', well, and you do think Louiſa handſome?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Handſome! Venus de Medicis was a ſybil to her.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Give me your hand, you little jocoſe rogue—Egad, I thought we had been all off.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: So! I was in hopes this would have been a quarrel; but I find the Jew is too cunning.

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Aye, this guſt of paſſion has made me dry—I am ſeldom ruffled; order ſome wine in the next room—let us drink the poor girl's health—poor Louiſa! ugly, heh! Ha, ha, ha! 'Twas a very good joke indeed.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: And a very true one for all that.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: And, Ferdinand, I inſiſt upon your drinking ſucceſs to my friend

sp.speaker: Ferd
sp.p: Sir, I will drink ſucceſs to my friend with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Come, little Solomon, if any ſparks of anger had remain'd, this would be the only way to quench them.

l.hi: A bumper of good liquor,
Will end a conteſt quicker,
Than juſtice, judge or vicar.
So fill a cheerful glaſs,
And let good humour paſs.
But if more deep the quarrel,
Why, ſooner drain the barrel,
Than be the hateful fellow,
That's crabbed when he is mellow.
A bumper, &c.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
Was ever truant daughter ſo whimſically circumſtanced as I am! I have ſent my intended huſband to look after my lover—the man of my father's choice is gone to bring me the man of my own, but how diſpiriting is this interval of expectation?
SONG.
What bard, O Time, diſcover,
With wings firſt made thee move;
Ah! ſure he was ſome lover,
Who ne'er had left his love.
For who that once did prove,
The pangs which abſence brings,
Tho' but one day,
He were away,
Could picture thee with wings,
Enter CARLOS. So, friend, is Antonio found?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I could not meet with him, lady; but I doubt not my friend Iſaac will be here with him preſently.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: O ſhame! you have uſed no diligence—Is this your courteſy to a lady who has truſted herſelf to your protection?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I have not been remiſs.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Well, well; but if either of you had known how each moment of delay weighs upon the heart of her who loves, and waits the object of her love, O, ye wou'd not then have trifled thus.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Alas! I know it well.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Were you ever in love then?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I was, lady: but while I have life will never be again.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Was your miſtreſs ſo cruel?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
If ſhe had always been ſo, I ſhou'd have been happier.
SONG.
O had my love ne'er ſmil'd on me,
I ne'er had known ſuch anguiſh;
But think how falſe, how cruel ſhe,
To bid me ceaſe to languiſh.
To bid me hope her hand to gain,
Breathe on a flame half periſh'd,
And then with cold and fix'd diſdain,
To kill the hope ſhe cheriſh'd.
Not worſe his fate, who on a wreck,
'That drove as winds did blow it,
Silent had left the ſhatter'd deck,
To find a grave below it.
Then land was cried—no more reſign'd,
He glow'd with joy to hear it,
Not worſe his fate, his woe to find,
The wreck muſt ſink e're near it.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: As I live, here is your friend coming with Antonio—I'll retire for a moment to ſurprize him. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Indeed, my good friend, you muſt be miſtaken. Clara D'Almanza in love with me, and employ you to bring me to meet her! It is impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: That you ſhall ſee in an inſtant—Carlos, where is the lady? (Carlos points to the door.) In the next room is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Nay, if that lady is really here, ſhe certainly wants me to conduct her to a dear friend of mine, who has long been her lover.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Pſha! I tell you 'tis no ſuch thing—you are the man ſhe wants, and nobody but you. Here's, ado to perſuade you to take a pretty girl that's dying for you.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: But I have no affection for this lady.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: And you have for Louiſa, hey? but take my word for it, Antonio, you have no chance there—ſo you may as well ſecure the good that offers itſelf to you.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: And could you reconcile it to your conſcience, to ſupplant your friend?

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Piſh! Conſcience has no more to do with gallantry that it has with politicks—why, you are no honeſt fellow, if love can't make a rogue of you—ſo come,—do go in and ſpeak to her at laſt.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Well, I have no objection to that.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: [opens the door] There—there ſhe is—yonder by the window—get in, do (puſhes him in, and half ſhuts the door) now, Carlos, now I ſhall hamper him I warrant—ſtay—I'll peep how they go on—egid, he looks conſoundedly poſed—now ſhe's coaxing him—ſee, Carlos, he begins to come to—aye, aye, he'll ſoon forget his conſcience.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Look! now they are both laughing

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye! ſo they are—yes, yes, they are laughing at that dear friend he talked of—aye poor devil, they have outwitted him.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Now he's kiſſing her hand.

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Yes, yes, faith, they're agreed—he's caught, he's entangled—my dear Carlos, we have brought it about. O, this little cunning head! I'm a Machiavel, a very Machiavel.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I hear ſomebody enquiring for you—I'll ſee who it is. [Exit Carlos.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Well, my good friend, this lady has ſo entirely convinc'd me of the certainty of your ſucceſs at Don Jerome's, that I now reſign my pretenſions there.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: You never did a wiſer thing, believe me—and as for deceiving your friend, that's nothing-at-all—tricking is all fair in love, isn't it, ma'am?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Certainly, ſir, and I am particularly glad to find you are of that opinion.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O lud, yes, ma'am—let any one outwit me that can, I ſay—but here let me join your hands—there, you lucky rogue, I wiſh you happily married from the bottom of my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And I am ſure, if you wiſh it, no one elſe ſhould prevent it.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Now, Antonio, we are rivals no more, ſo let us be friends, will you?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: With all my heart, Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: It is not every man, let me tell you, that would have taken ſuch pains, or been ſo generous to a rival.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: No, faith, I don't believe there's another beſide yourſelf in all Spain.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, but you reſign all pretenſions to the other lady?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: That I do moſt ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I doubt you have a little hankering there ſtill.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: None in the leaſt, upon my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I mean after her fortune?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: No, believe me. You are heartily welcome to every thing ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, I'faith, you have the beſt of the bargain as to beauty, twenty to one—now I'll tell you a ſecret—I am to carry off Louiſa this very evening.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe has ſworn not to take a huſband from her father's hand—ſo, I've perſuaded him to truſt her to walk with me in the garden, and then we ſhall give him the ſlip.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And is Don Jerome to know nothing of this?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p:
O lud no: there lies the jeſt! Don't you ſee that, by this ſtep, I over-reach him, I ſhall be entitled
to the girl's fortune without ſettling a ducat on her, ha, ha, ha! I'm a cunning dog, a'n't I? A fly little villain, heh?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! you are indeed!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Roguiſh you'll ſay—but keen, hey?—deviliſh keen?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: So you are indeed—keen—very keen.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: And what a laugh we ſhall have at Don Jerome's, when the truth comes out, hey?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, I'll anſwer for't, we ſhall have a good laugh when the truth comes out, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Here are the dancers come to practice the fandango you intended to have honour'd Donna Louiſa with.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O, I ſha'n't want them, but as I muſt pay them, I'll ſee a caper for my money—will you excuſe me?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Here's my friend, whom you may command for any ſervices, Madam, your moſt obedient—Antonio, I wiſh you all happineſs. O the eaſy blockhead! what a tool I have made of him?—This was a maſter piece. [Exit Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Carlos, will you be my guard again, and convey me to the convent of St. Catherine?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Why, Louiſa, why ſhould you go there?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I have my reaſons, and you muſt not be ſeen to go with me; I ſhall write from thence to my father, perhaps, when he finds what he has driven me to, he may relent.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: I have no hope from him—O Louiſa, in theſe arms ſhould be your ſanctuary.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Be patient but for a little while—my father cannot force me from thence. But let me ſee you there before evening, and I will explain myſelf.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: I ſhall obey.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, friend—Antonio, Carlos has been a lover himſelf.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Then he knows the value of his truſt.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: You ſhall not find me unfaithful.

l.hi: Soft pity never leaves the gentle breaſt,
Where love has been receiv'd a welcome gueſt,
As wand'ring ſaints poor huts have ſacred made,
He hallows ev'ry heart he once has ſway'd;
And when his preſence we no longer ſhare,
Still leaves compaſſion as a relic there.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, I never was ſo amazed in my life! Louiſa gone off with Iſaac Mendoza! what, ſteal away with the very man whom I wanted her to marry—elope with her own huſband as it were—it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Her maid ſays, ſir, they had your leave to walk in the garden while you was abroad: The door by the ſhrubbery was found open, and they have not been heard of ſince.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Well, it is the moſt unaccountable affair! s'de th, there is certainly ſome infernal myſtery in it, I can't comprehend.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here is a letter, ſir, from Signor Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: So, ſo, this will explain—ay, "Iſaac Mendoza," let me ſee. (Reads.) "Deareſt ſir, you muſt, doubtleſs, be much ſurprized at my flight with your daughter"—Yes, faith, and well I may. "I had the happineſs to gain her heart at our firſt interview"—The devil you had!—"But ſhe having unfortunately made a vow not to receive a huſband from your hands, I was obliged to comply with her whim" So, ſo! "We ſhall ſhortly throw ourſelves at your feet, and I hope you will have a bleſſing, ready for one who will then be Your ſon-in-law, ISAAC MENDOZA."

A whim, heigh? Why the devil's in the girl I think—This morning ſhe would die ſooner than have him, and before evening ſhe runs away with him. Well, well, my will's accompliſhed—let the motive be what it will—and the Portugueze, ſure, will never deny to fulfil the reſt of the article.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, here's a man below who ſays he brought this from my young lady, Donna Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
How! yes, it is my daughter's hand indeed! Lord, there was no occaſion for them both to write; well, let's ſee what ſhe ſays: (reads) "My deareſt father, how ſhall I intreat your pardon for the raſh ſtep I have taken, how confeſs the motive?" Piſh! hasn't Iſaac juſt told me the motive? one would think they weren't together when they wrote. "If I have a ſpirit too reſentful of ill uſage, I have alſo a heart as eaſily affected by kindneſs"—So, ſo, here the whole matter comes out, her reſentment
for Antonio's ill uſage, has made her ſenſible of Iſaac's kindneſs—yes, yes, it is all plain enough—well "—I am not married yet, tho' with a man I am convinced adores me"—Yes, yes, I dare ſay Iſaac is very fond of her—"but I ſhall anxiouſly expect your anſwer, in which, ſhould I be ſo fortunate as to receive your conſent, you will make completely happy, Your ever affectionate daughter, LOUISA."
My conſent! to be ſure ſhe ſhall have it; egad, I was never better pleaſed—I have fulfilled my reſolution—I knew I ſhould—O there's nothing like obſtinacy—Lewis?
Let the man who brought the laſt letter wait, and get me a pen and ink below. I am impatient to ſet poor Louiſa's heart at reſt, holloa! Lewis! Sancho!
See that there be a noble ſupper provided in the Saloon to-night—ſerve up my beſt wines, and let me have muſic, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p:
And order all my doors to be thrown open—admit all gueſts with maſks or without maſks—I'faith, we'll have a might of it—And I'll let them ſee how merry an old man can be.
SONG.
O the days when I was young,
When I laugh'd at fortune's ſpight,
Talk'd of love the whole day long,
And with nectar crown'd the night,
Then it was old father Care,
Little-reck'd I of thy frown,
Half thy malice youth could bear,
And the reſt a bumper drown.
Truth they ſay lies in a well,
Why I vow I ne'er could ſee,
Let the water drinkers tell,
There it always lay for me.
For when ſparkling wine went round,
Never ſaw I falſehoods maſk,
But ſtill honeſt truth I found,
In the bottom of each flaſk.
True, at length my vigour's flown,
I have years to bring decay;
Few the locks that now Town,
And the few I have, are grey.
Yet, old Jerome, thou may'ſt boaſt,
While thy ſpirits do not tire,
Still beneath thy age's froſt;
Glows a ſpark of youthful fire.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand.
sp.p: What, cou'd you gather no tidings of her? Nor gueſs where ſhe was gone? O Clara! Clara!

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: In truth, Sir, I could not—that ſhe was run away from her father, was in every body's mouth,—and that Don Guzman was in purſuit of her, was alſo a very common report—where ſhe was gone, or what was become of her, no one could take upon 'em to ſay.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand.
sp.p: S'death and fury, you blockhead, ſhe cant be out of Seville.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: So I ſaid to myſelf, Sir! S'death and fury, you blockhead, ſays I, ſhe can't be out of Seville—then ſome ſaid, ſhe had hang'd herſelf for love, and others have it, Don Antonio had carried her off.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe, ſcoundrel! no one ſaid that.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Then I miſunderſtood 'em, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ferdinand.
sp.p: Go, fool, get home, and never let me ſee you again, till you bring me news of her. [Exit Lopez.

O! how my fondneſs for this ungrateful girl, has hurt my diſpoſition?
SONG.
Ah, cruel maid, how haſt thou changed
The temper of my mind?
My heart by thee from mirth eſtrang'd
Becomes, like thee, unkind.
By fortune favour'd, clear in fame
I once ambitious was;
And friends I had, that fann'd the flame,
And gave my youth applauſe.
But now my weakneſs all abuſe,
Yet vain their taunts on me;
Friends, fortune, fame itſelf I'd loſe,
To gain one ſmile from thee.
Yet, only thou ſhouldſt not deſpiſe
My folly, or my woe;
If I am mad in others eyes,
'Tis thou haſt made me ſo.
But days like theſe, with doubting curſt
I will not long endure;
Am I deſpiſed, I know the worſt,
And alſo know my cure
If falſe, her vows ſhe dare renounce,
She inſtant ends my pain,
For, Oh, that heart muſt break at once;
Which cannot bate-again.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p:
So, I have her ſafe—and have only to find
a prieſt to marry us, Antonio now may marry Clara, or not, if he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What? what was that you ſaid of Clara?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O Ferdinand! my brother-in-law that ſhall be, who thought of meeting you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But what of Clara?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I'faith, you ſhall hear.—This morning as I was coming down, I met a pretty damſel, who told me her name was Clara d'Almanza, and begg'd my protection.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: She ſaid ſhe had eloped from her father, Don Guzman, but that love for a young gentleman in Seville, was the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: O heavens! did ſhe confeſs it?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O yes, ſhe confeſs'd at once—but then, ſays the, my lover is not inform'd of my flight, nor ſuſpects my intention.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Dear creature! no more I did indeed! O, I am the happieſt fellow—well, Iſaac! [aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, then ſhe intreated me to find him out for her, and bring him to her.

sp.speaker: Ferd
sp.p: Good heavens, how lucky! well, come along, let's loſe no time. [pulling him.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Zooks! where are we to go?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Why, did any thing more paſs?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Any thing more!—yes, the end on't was, that I was moved with her ſpeeches, and complied with her deſires.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well, and where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Where is ſhe? why, don't I tell you I complied with her requeſt, and left her ſafe in the arms of her lover.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: S'death! you trifle with me—I have never ſeen her.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: You! O lud, no! How the devil ſhou'd you? 'Twas Antonio ſhe wanted, and with Antonio I left her.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Hell and madneſs (aſide) what Antonio d'Ercilla?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, the very man; and the beſt part
of it was, he was ſhy of taking her at firſt—He talk'd a good deal about honor and conſcience, and deceiving ſome dear friend; but, lord, we ſoon over ruled that.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O yes, preſently—ſuch deceit, ſays he—Piſh! ſays the lady, tricking is all fair in love—but then, my friend, ſays he—Pſha! damn your friend, ſays I—ſo, poor wretch, he has no chance—no, no—he may hang himſelf as ſoon as he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I muſt go, or I ſhall betray myſelf.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: But ſtay, Ferdinand, you han't heard the beſt of the joke.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Curſe on your joke.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Goodlack! what's the matter now? I thought to have diverted you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Be rack'd, tortur'd, damn'd—

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, ſure you're not the poor devil of a lover are you? I'faith, as ſure as can be, he is—this is a better joke than t'other, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What do you laugh, you vile, miſchievous varlet (collars him) but that you're beneath my anger; I'd tear your heart out. [Throws him from him.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O mercy! here's uſage for a brother in-law!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But, harky, raſcall tell me directly where theſe falſe friends are gone, or by my ſoul (draws)

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: For heavens ſake, now, my dear brother-in-law, don't be in a rage—I'll recollect as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Be quick then!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I will, I will—but people's memories differ—ſome have a treacherous memory—now mine is a cowardly memory—it takes to its heels at ſight of a drawn ſword, it does I'faith—and I could as ſoon fight as recollect.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Zounds, tell me the truth, and I won't hurt you.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, no; I know you won't, my dear brother-in-law—but that ill looking thing there.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What, then, you won't tell me?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will—I'll tell you all upon my ſoul, but why need you liſten ſword in hand?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Why there (puts up) now.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why then, I believe they are gone to—that is my friend, Carlos, told me he had left Donna Clara—dear Ferdinand keep your hands off—at the Convent of St. Catherine.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: St. Catherine!

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes; and that Antonio was to come to her there.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Is this the truth?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: It is indeed; and all I know, as I hope for life.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well, coward, take your life—'tis that falſe, diſhonourable Antonio, who ſhall feel my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Ay, ay, kill him—cut his throat and welcome.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But for Clara—infamy on her—ſhe is not worth my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No more ſhe is, my dear brother-in-law, I'faith I would not be angry about her—ſhe is not worth it indeed.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe—ſhe is worth the enmity of princes.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: True, true; ſo ſhe is, and I pity you exceedingly for having loſt her.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: S'death, you raſcal! how durſt you talk of pitying me.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O dear brother-in law, I beg pardon—I don't pity you in the leaſt, upon my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Get hence, fool, and-provoke me no further—Nothing but your inſignificance ſaves you.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I'faith, then my inſignificance is the beſt friend I have—I'm going, dear Ferdinand—What a curſt, hot headed bully it is!

div.head: SCENE III. —The Garden of the Convent.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And you really wiſh my brother may not find you out?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Why elſe, have I conceal'd myſelf under this diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Why, perhaps, becauſe the dreſs becomes you, for you certainly don't intend to be a nun for life.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: If, indeed, Ferdinand had not offended me ſo, laſt night.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, come, it was his fear of loſing you, made him ſo raſh.

sp.speaker: Clara
sp.p: Well, you may think me cruel—but I ſwear, if he were here this inſtant, I believe I ſhou'd forgive him.

l.hi: By him we love offended,
How ſoon our anger flies,
One day apart, 'tis ended,
Behold him and it dies,
Laſt night, your roving brother,
Enrag'd I bade depart,
And ſure his rude preſumption,
Deſerv'd to loſe my heart.
Yet, were he now before me,
In ſpite of injured pride,
I fear my eyes wou'd pardon,
Before my tongue cou'd chide.
With truth, the bold deceiver,
To me thus oft has ſaid,
No frowns appear reſentful,
Where Heaven has ſtampt a ſmile.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I proteſt, Clara, I ſhall begin to think you are ſeriouſly reſolved to enter on your probation.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And, ſeriouſly, I very much doubt whether the character of a nun wou'd not become me beſt.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, the character of a nun is a very becoming one—at a maſquerade—but no pretty woman in her ſenſes ever thought of taking the veil for above a night.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Yonder I ſee your Antonio is returned—I ſhall only interrupt you; ah, Louiſa, with what happy eagerneſs you turn to look for him!

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Well, my Louiſa, any news ſince I left you?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: None—The meſſenger is not returned from my father.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Well, I confeſs, I do not perceive what we are to expect from him.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I ſhall be eaſier however, in having made the trial, I do not doubt your ſincerity, Antonio: but there is a chilling air round poverty that often kills affection, that was not nurs'd in it—If we would make love our houſehold god, we had beſt ſecure him a comfortable roof. [Enter Maid, with a letter.
My father's anſwer I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: My deareſt Louiſa, you may be aſſured that it contains nothing but threats and reproaches.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
Let us ſee however (reads) "Deareſt daughter, make your lover happy, you have my
full conſent to marry as your whim has choſen, but be ſure come home to ſup with your affectionate father."

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: You jeſt, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (Gives him the Letter) Read—read.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, by heavens! ſure there muſt be ſome miſtake; but that's none of our buſineſs—now, Louiſa, you have no excuſe for delay.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Shall we not then return and thank my father?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: But firſt let the prieſt put it out of his power to recall his word—I'll fly to procure one.

sp.speaker: Louiſa
sp.p: Nay; if you part with me again, perhaps you may loſe me.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Come then—there is a friar of a neighbouring convent is my friend; you have already been diverted by the manners of a nunnery—let us ſee, whether there is leſs hypocriſy among the holy fathers.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I'm afraid not, Antonio—for in religion, as in friendſhip, they who profeſs moſt are ever the leaſt ſincere. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So, yonder they go, as happy as a mutual and confeſs'd affection can make them; while I am left in ſolitude. Heigho! love may perhaps excuſe the raſhneſs of an elopement from one's friend; but I am ſure; nothing but the preſence of the man we love can ſupport it—Ha! what do I ſee; Ferdinand as I live, how cou'd he gain admiſſion—by potent gold I ſuppoſe, as Antonio did—how eager and diſturbed he ſeems—he ſhall not know me as yet. [Lets down her veil.]

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yes, thoſe were certainly they—my infortion was right. [going.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: (Stops him) Pray, Signor, what is your buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: No matter—no matter—Oh, they ſtop— (looks out) yes, that is the perfidious Clara indeed.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: So, a jealous error—I'm glad to ſee him ſo mov'd. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Her diſguiſe can't conceal her—No, no, I know her too well.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Wonderful diſcernment! but Signor—

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Be quiet, good nun, don't teize me—by heavens ſhe leans upon his arm, hangs fondly on it! O woman! woman!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But, Signior, who is it you want?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Not you, not you, ſo, prythee don't teize me. Yet pray ſtay—gentle nun, was it not Donna Clara d'Almanza juſt parted from you?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Clara d'Almanza, Signor, is not yet out of the garden.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I knew I was right—and pray, is not that gentleman now at the porch with her, Antonio d'Ercilla?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It is indeed, Signior.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: So, ſo, now but one queſtion more—can you inform me for what purpoſe they have gone away?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: They are gone to be married, I believe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Very well—enough—now if I don't marr their wedding. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p:
(unveils) I thought jealouſy had made lovers quick-ſighted, but it has made mine blind—Louiſa's ſtory accounts to me for this error, and I am glad to find I have power enough over him to make him ſo happy—but why ſhould not I be preſent at his ſurprize when undeceived? When he's thro' the porch I'll follow him, and, perhaps, Louiſa ſhall not ſingly be a bride.
SONG.
Adieu, thou dreary pile, where never dies,
The ſullen echo of repentant ſighs:
Ye ſiſter mourners of each lonely cell,
Inured to hymns and ſorrow, fare ye well;
For happier ſcenes I fly this darkſome grove,
To ſaints a priſon, but a tomb to love.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: What my friend Iſaac:

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: What, Antonio! wiſh me joy! I have Louiſa ſafe.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Have you? I wiſh you joy with all my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, I am come here to procure a prieſt to marry us.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: So, then we are both on the ſame errand, I am come to look for Father Paul.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Hah! I am glad on't—but I'faith he muſt tack me firſt, my love is waiting.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: So is mine—I left her in the porch.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye, but I am in haſte to get back to Don Jerome.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: And ſo am I too.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, perhaps he'll ſave time and marry us both together—or I'll be your father and you ſhall be mine—Come along—but you're obliged to me for all this.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

div.head: SCENE V. —A Room in the Priory.

l.hi: This bottle's the ſun of our table,
His beams are roſy wine;
We, planets that are not able,
Without his help to ſhine,
Let mirth and glee abound,
You'll ſoon grow bright,
With borrow'd light;
And ſhine as he goes round.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Brother Francis, toſs the bottle about, and give me your toaſt.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: Have we drank the abbeſs of St. Urſuline?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Yes, yes; ſhe was the laſt.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: Then I'll give you the blue-eyed nun of St. Catherine's.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: With all my heart (drinks). Pray brother Auguſtine, were there any benefactions left in my abſence?

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: Don Juan Carduba has left an hundred ducats to remember him in our maſſes.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Has he! let them be paid to our wine merchant, and we'll remember him in our cups, which will do juſt as well. Any thing more?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Yes; Baptiſta, the rich miſer, who died laſt week, has bequeath'd us a thouſand piſtoles, and the ſilver lamp he uſed in his own chamber, to burn before the image of St. Anthony.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: 'Twas well meant; but we'll employ his money better—Baptiſta's bounty ſhall light the living, not the dead—St. Anthony is not afraid to be left in the dark, though he was—ſee who's there. [A knocking, Francis goes to the door and opens it.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Here's one without in preſſing haſte to ſpeak with Father Paul.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Brother Paul! [Paul comes from behind a curtain, with a glaſs of wine, and in his hand a piece of cake]

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Here! how durſt you, fellow, thus abruptly break in upon our devotions?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: I thought they were finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: No they were not—were they, brother Francis?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Not by a bottle each.

sp.speaker: Paul.
