sp.p: But neither you or your fellows mark how the hours go—no, you mind nothing but the gratifying of your appetites; ye eat and ſwill, and ſleep, and gormandize, and thrive while we are waſting in mortification.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: We aſk no more than nature craves.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe, ye have more appetites than hairs, and your fluſh'd, ſleek, and pampered appearance is the diſgrace of our order—out on't—if you are hungry, can't you be content with the wholeſome roots of the earth, and if you are dry, isn't there the cryſtal ſpring (drinks)? Put this away (gives a glaſs) and ſhew me where I'm wanted. (Porter drains the glaſs—Paul going, turns) —ſo, you wou'd have drank it, if there had been any left. Ah, glutton! glutton!

div.head: SCENE VI. —The Court before the Priory.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: A plaguy while coming this ſame father Paul—He's detain'd at veſpers I ſuppoſe, poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: No, here he comes. Good father Paul, (Enter Paul) I crave your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes good father Paul, we are come to beg a favour.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: What is it pray?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: To marry us, good father Paul; and in truth, thou do'ſt look the very prieſt of Hymen.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: In ſhort I may be called ſo; for I deal in repentance and mortification.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, no, thou ſeem'ſt an officer of Hymen, becauſe thy preſence ſpeaks content and good humour.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Alas! my appearance is deceitful. Bloated I am, indeed, for faſting is a windy recreation, and it hath ſwoln me like a bladder.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: But thou haſt a good freſh colour in thy face, father, roſy I'faith.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Yes, I have bluſh'd for mankind, till the hue of my ſhame is as fixed as their vices.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Good man!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: And I have labour'd too—but to what purpoſe? they continue to ſin under my very noſe.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Eſecks, father, I ſhou'd have gueſs'd as much, for your noſe ſeems to be put to the bluſh more than any other part of your face.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Go, you're a wag.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: But to the purpoſe, father—will you officiate for us?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: To join young people thus clandeſtinely is not ſafe, and indeed, I have in my heart many weighty reaſons againſt it.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: And I have in my hand many weighty reaſons for it.—Iſaac, hav'n't you an argument or two in our favour about you?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, yes; here is a moſt unanſwerable purſe.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: For ſhame, you make me angry; you forget that I am a Jacobin, and when importunate people have forced their traſh—aye, into this pocket here—or into this—why, then the ſin was theirs (they put money into his pockets) fie! now, how you diſtreſs me?—I wou'd return it, but that I muſt touch it that way, and ſo wrong my oath.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Now then, come with us.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye, now give us your title to joy and rapture.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Well, when your hour of repentance comes, don't blame me.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: No bad caution to my friend Iſaac (aſide). Well, well, father, do you do your part and I'll abide the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye, and ſo will I (they are going.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: O, Antonio, Ferdinand is at the porch and enquiring for us.

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Who? Don Ferdinand! he's not enquiring for me I hope.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Fear not, my love, I'll ſoon paciſy him.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Egad, you won't—Antonio, take my advice and run away; this Ferdinand is the moſt unmerciful dog! and has the curſedeſt long ſword! and upon my ſoul he comes on purpoſe to cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Never fear, never fear.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Well, you may ſtay if you will—but I'll get ſome one to marry me, for by St. Iago, he ſhall never marry me again, while I am maſter of a pair of heels. [Runs out.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: So, Sir, I have met with you at laſt.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Baſe treacherous man! whence can a falſe, deceitful ſoul like your's borrow confidence to look ſo ſteadily on the man you've injured?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p:
Ferdinand, you are too warm—'tis true you find me on the point of wedding one I love beyond my life, but no argument of mine prevail'd on her to elope—I ſcorn deceit as much as you
—by heav'n, I knew not ſhe had leſt her father's till I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What a mean excuſe! you have wrong'd your friend then, for one, whoſe wanton forwardneſs anticipated your treachery—of this indeed, your Jew pander inform'd me; but let your conduct be conſiſtent, and ſince you have dar'd to do a wrong, follow me, and ſhew you have ſpirit to avow it.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Antonio, I perceive his miſtake—leave him to me.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Friend, you are rude to interrupt the union of two willing hearts.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: No, meddling prieſt, the hand he ſeeks is mine.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: If ſo, I'll proceed no further—lady, did you ever promiſe this youth your hand? [To Louiſa, who ſhakes her head.]

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Clara, I thank you for your ſilence—I would not ſave heard your tongue avow ſuch falſity—be't your puniſhment to remember I have not reproached you—Antonio, you are protected now, but we ſhall meet. [Going, Clara holds one arm and Louiſa the other.]

l.hi: Turn thee round I pray thee,
Calm awhile thy rage,
I muſt help to ſtay thee,
And thy wrath aſſuage.
Could'ſt thou not diſcover
One ſo dear to thee?
Can'ſt thou be a lover,
And thus fly from me?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: How's this! my ſiſter! Clara too—I'm confounded.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: 'Tis even ſo, good brother.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: How! what impiety! Did the man want to marry his own ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And arn't you aſham'd of yourſelf not to know your own ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: To drive away your own miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Don't you ſee how jealouſy blinds people?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Aye, and will you ever be jealous again?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Never—never—you, ſiſter, I know will forgive me—but now, Clara, ſhall I preſume—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: No, no, juſt now you told me not to teize you "Who do you want, good Signior?" "not you, not you." O you blind wretch! but ſwear never to be jealous again, and I'll forgive you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: By all—

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: There, that will do—you'll keep the oath juſt as well. [gives her hand.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But, brother, here is one, to whom ſome apology is due.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Antonio, I am aſham'd to think—

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Not a word of excuſe, Ferdinand—I have not been in love myſelf, without learning that a lover's anger ſhou'd never be reſented—but come—let us retire with this good father, and we'll explain to you the cauſe of this error.

l.hi: Oft' does Hymen ſmile to hear,
Wordy vows of feign'd regard;
Well he knows when they're ſincere.
Never ſlow to give reward:
For his glory is to prove,
Kind to thoſe who wed for love.

div.head: SCENE VII. —and Laſt. A Grand Saloon.
div.stage: Enter DON JEROME, SERVANTS and LOPEZ.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Be ſure now let every thing be in the beſt order—let all my Servants have on their merrieſt faces—but tell 'em to get as little drunk as poſſible till after ſupper. So, Lopez, where's your maſter? ſha'n't we have him at ſupper?

sp.speaker: Lopez
sp.p: Indeed, I believe not, Sir—he's mad, I doubt; I'm ſure he has frighted me from him.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Aye, aye, he's after ſome wench, I ſuppoſe, a young rake! Well, well, we'll be merry without him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, here is Signior Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: So, my dear ſon-in law—there, take my bleſſing and forgiveneſs, but where's my daughter? where's Louiſa?

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: She's without impatient for a bleſſing, but almoſt afraid to enter.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: O fly and bring her in. [Exit Iſaac.
Poor girl, I long to ſee her pretty face.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: (without) Come, my charmer! my trembling Angel!

div.stage: Enter ISAAC and DUENNA, DON JEROME runs to meet them (ſhe kneels.)

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Come to my arms. my— (ſtarts back) why who the devil have we here?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Nay, Don Jerome, you promiſed her forgiveneſs; ſee how dear 〈…〉 droops

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Droops indeed! Why, gad take me this is ſo Margaret—but where's my daughter, where's Louiſa?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why here, before your eyes—nay, don't be ab • ſhed, my ſweet wife!

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Wi • e with a vengeance! Why, zounds you have not married the Duenna!

sp.speaker: Margaret.
sp.p: (Kneeling) O dear papa! you'll not diſown me ſure!

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Papa! dear papa! Why, zounds, your impudence is as great as your uglineſs.

sp.speaker: Iſaac
sp.p: Riſe, my charmer, go throw your ſnowy arms about his neck, and convince him you are—

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: O Sir, ſo give me! [Embraces him.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Help! murder!

sp.speaker: Servants
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why here, this damn'd Jew has brought an old Harridan to ſtrangle me.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Lord, it is his own daughter, and he is ſo hard hearted he won't forgive her.

div.stage: Enter ANTONIO and LOUISA, they kneel.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Zounds and ſury, what's here now? who ſent for you, Sir, and who the devil are you?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: This lady's huſband, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye, that he is I'll be ſworn; for I left 'em with the Prieſt, and was to have given her away.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: You were?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Aye; that's my honeſt friend, Antonio; and that's the little girl I told you I had hamper'd him with.

sp.speaker: Jerome
sp.p: Why, you are either drunk or mad—this is my daughter.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: No, no; 'tis you are both drunk and mad, I think—here's your daughter.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Hark'ee, old iniquity, will you explain all this or not?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Come then, Don Jerome, I will—tho' our habits might inform you all—look on your daughter there, and on me.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: The truth is, that in your paſſion this morning, you made a ſmall miſtake, for you turn'd your daughter out of doors, and lock'd up your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: O lud! O lud! here's a pretty fellow! to turn his daughter out of doors inſtead of an old Duenna.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: And, O lud! O lud! here's a pretty fellow to marry an old Duenna inſtead of my daughter—but how came the reſt about?

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: I have only to add, that I remain'd in your daughter's place, and had the good fortune to engage the affections of my ſweet huſband here.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Her huſband! why, you old witch, do you think I'll be your huſband now! this is a trick, a cheat, and you ought all to be aſham'd of yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Iſaac, do you dare to complain of tricking—Don Jerome, I give you my ſword, this cunning Portugueze has brought all this upon himſelf, by endeavouring to over reach you by getting your daughter's fortune, without making any ſettlement in return.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Over-reach me!

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo indeed, Sir, and we can prove it to you.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, gad take me, it muſt be ſo, or he cou'd never have put up with ſuch a face as Margaret's—ſo, little Solomon, I wiſh you joy of your wife with all my ſol.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Iſaac, tricking is all fair in love—let you alone for the plot.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: A cunning dog ar'n't you? A ſly little villain, heh!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Roguiſh, perhaps; but keen, deviliſh keen.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Yes, yes, his aunt always call'd him little Solomon.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Why, the plague of Egypt upon you all—but do you think I'll ſubmit to ſuch an impoſition?

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Iſaac, one ſerious word—you'd better be content as you are, for believe me, you will find, that in the opinion of the world, there is not a fairer ſubject for contempt and ridicule, than a knave become the dupe of his own art.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I don't care—I'll not endure this—Don Jerome, 'tis you have done this—you wou'd be ſo curſt poſitive about the beauty of her you lock'd up, and all the time, I told you ſhe was as old as my mother, and as ugly as the Devil.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Why you little inſignificant reptile.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: That's right—attack him, Margaret.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Dares ſuch a thing as you pretend to talk of beauty—a walking rouleau—a body that ſeems to owe all its conſequence to the dropſy—a pair of eyes like two dead beetles in a wad of brown dough. A beard like an artichoke, with dry ſhrivell'd jaws that wou'd diſgrace the mummy of a monkey.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Well done, Margaret.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: But you ſhall know that I have a brother who wears a ſword, and if you don't do me juſtice—

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Fire ſeize your brother, and you too—I'll fly to Jeruſalem to avoid you.

sp.speaker: Duenna.
sp.p: Fly where you will, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Throw your ſnowy arms about him, Margaret. [Exeunt Iſaac and Duenna.
But Louiſa, are you really married to this modeſt gentleman?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, in obedience to your commands I gave him my hand within this hour.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: My commands!

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, here is your conſent under your own hand.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: How? wou'd you rob me of my child by a trick, a falſe pretence, and do you think to get her fortune by the ſame means? why s'life, you are as great a rogue as Iſaac.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: No, Don Jerome, tho' I have profited by this paper in gaining your daughter's hand, I ſcorn to obtain her fortune by deceit, there Sir, [Gives a letter] now give her your bleſſing for a dower, and all the little I poſſeſs, ſhall be ſettled on her in return. Had you wedded her to a prince, he could do no more.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Why, gad take me, but you are a very extraordinary fellow, but have you the impudence to ſuppoſe no one can do a generous action but yourſelf? Here Louiſa, tell this proud fool of yours, that he's the only man I know that wou'd renounce your fortune; and by my ſoul, he's the only man in Spain that's worthy of it—there, bleſs you both, I'm an obſtinate old fellow when I am in the wrong; but you ſhall now find me as ſteady in the right.
Another wonder ſtill! why, Sirrah! Ferdinand, you have not ſtole a nun, have you?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: She is a nun in nothing but her habit, Sir—look nearer, and you will perceive 'tis Clara d'Almanza, Don Guzman's daughter, and with pardon for ſtealing a wedding, ſhe is alſo my wiſe.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Gadlbud, and a great fortune—Ferdinand, you are a prudent young rogue and I forgive you; and iſecks you are a pretty little damſel. Give your father-in-law a kiſs, you ſmiling rogue.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: There old gentleman, and now mind you behave well to us.

sp.speaker: Jerome.
sp.p: Eſecks, thoſe lips ha'n't been chill'd by kiſſing beads—Egad, I believe I ſhall grow the beſt humour'd fellow in Spain—Lewis, Sancho, Carlos, d'ye hear, are all my doors thrown open? Our childrens weddings are the only hollidays our age can boaſt, and then we drain with pleaſure, the little ſtock of ſpirits time has left us. [Muſic within] But ſee, here come our friends and neighbours.
And I'faith we'll make a night on't, with wine and dance, and catches—then old and young ſhall join us.

l.hi: Come now for jeſt and ſmiling,
Both old and young beguiling,
Let us laugh and play, ſo blyth and gay,
Till we baniſh care away.
Thus crown'd with dance and ſong,
The hours ſhall glide along,
With a heart at eaſe, merry, merry glees,
Can never fail to pleaſe.
Each bride with bluſhes glowing,
Our wine as roſy flowing,
Let us laugh and play, ſo blythe and gay,
Till we baniſh care away,—
Then, health's to every friend,
The night's repaſt ſhall end,
With a heart at eaſe, merry, merry glees,
Can never fail to pleaſe.
Nor while we are jo joyous,
Shall anxious fear annoy us,
Let us laugh and play, ſo blythe and gay,
Till we baniſh care away.
For generous gueſts like theſe,
Accept the wiſh to pleaſe,
So we'll laugh and play, ſo blythe and gay,
Your ſmiles drive care away.
